questions.text: In 1990, for the first time, Michaele Blease and W. French Andresco of the National Institute of Health, Bethesda, U.S.A. attempted gene therapy on a human patient. Which of the following disease was attempted to be cured?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Disease The first convincing therapeutic effect from gene transfer occurred with: SCID Important types of defects in SCID X-linked Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Disease (SCID): mutations in the gene (IL2RG). IL2RG encodes γ c subunit of cytokine receptors. Inheritance pattern: X-Linked. The most common cause of SCID is IL2R defect. Autosomal Recessive SCID: ADA (Adenosine Deaminase enzyme) deficiency. Gene therapy is done for ADA deficiency SCID.

questions.text: Change in the number of trinucleotide sequence repeats is involved in giving rise to certain disorders. All of the following diseases are due to an excessive number of glutamine residues (trinucleotide CAG repeat extension) in proteins, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myotonic dystrophy Myotonic dystrophy is due to ↑ CTG repeat , not CAG Codon CAG codes for glutamine (Q) Poly Q disorders Those diseases which are due to CAG repeat e .g. Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease) Spinocerebellar ataxia Huntington’s disease. Other Disorders: Disease Repeat Fragile X syndrome CGG Friedreich’s Ataxia GAA

questions.text: The ring in the nitrogenous bases of DNA has a system of conjugated double bonds hence absorbing UV light like aromatic amino acids. This is a very valuable tool to measure DNA/RNA concentration in purified nucleic acids samples using UV spectrophotometry. Nucleic acids as a whole absorb UV light maximally at the wavelength of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

260nm Nucleic acids absorb UV light maximally at the wavelength of 260 nm 260/280 ratio of pure DNA/RNA is in the range of 1.8 to 2. Amino acids absorb UV light (not visible light) → colorless. Aromatic amino acids absorb UV light at 250-290 nm (maximum absorption is at 280 nm) because of conjugated double bonds.

questions.text: Analysis of one strand of a double-stranded piece of DNA displayed 25 mol % A, 20 mol % T, 35 mol % G, and 20 mol % C. Which one of the following accurately represents the composition of the complementary strand?

options.label: A
options.text: [A] is 25 mol %, [T] is 20 mol %, [G] is 35 mol %, and [C] is 20 mol %.

options.label: B
options.text: [A] is 20 mol %, [T] is 25 mol %, [G] is 20 mol %, and [C] is 35 mol %.

options.label: C
options.text: [U] is 20 mol %, [T] is 25 mol %, [G] is 20 mol %, and [C] is 35 mol %.

options.label: D
options.text: The composition of the complementary strand cannot be determined from the data given.

questions.correct_answer: B. [A] is 20 mol %, [T] is 25 mol %, [G] is 20 mol %, and [C] is 35 mol %.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

[A] is 20 mol %, [T] is 25 mol %, [G] is 20 mol %, and [C] is 35 mol %. In a double-stranded DNA , Chargaff's rule is followed That is the base pairs in double-stranded DNA require that [A] = [T], and [C] = [G]. Therefore, if the concentration of A in one strand is 25 mol %, the concentration of T in the complementary strand must also be 25 mol %. Hence the base composition of the complementary strand is: In given strand In complementary strand A = 25 T = 25 T = 20 A = 20 G= 35 C= 35 C= 20 G = 20 Note: Chargaff’s rule is not applicable for RNA and ssDNA

questions.text: The process of gene regulation involves the folding and unfolding of tightly packed DNA. This occurs by binding a variety of proteins and enzymes at the DNA surface through charge-charge interactions. At physiologic pH, the charge present in DNA is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Negative charge Nucleic acid carries a negative charge at physiological pH The negative charge at physiologic pH is due to the presence of the Phosphate backbone which provides a uniform negative charge on the outside. This property is useful for the separation of DNA or RNA by electrophoresis . DNA will move toward the anode. Shorter DNA molecules will move faster than longer molecules in agarose gel electrophoresis and get separated.

questions.text: Nucleosomes are a fundamental unit of DNA organization. It consists of histones complexed to DNA. Histone proteins present in nucleosomes are rich in which of the following amino acids?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lysine and Arginine Histone proteins : Rich in positively charged amino acids, lysine, and arginine. Carboxyl terminal 2/3rd of histone molecules are hydrophobic. Amino-terminals 1/3rd are particularly rich in basic amino acids. This amino-terminal end protrudes out of the octamer and is known as the histone tail. Amino acids of histone tail undergo post-translational modifications.

questions.text: About nucleotides in DNA, all the following are correct, EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: The nucleotide is formed by a combination of purine/pyrimidine base, sugar, and phosphoric acid.

options.label: B
options.text: The 3′ hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5′ hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group.

options.label: C
options.text: Nucleotides are linked by 3′ to 5′ phosphodiester bonds to form long polynucleotide chains

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above All the above statements are true. Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is composed of 4 types of deoxyribonucleotides, i.e. Deoxyadenylate (AMP) Deoxyguanylate (GMP) Deoxycytidylate (CMP) Deoxythymidylate (TMP) The nucleotide is formed by a combination of base + sugar + phosphoric acid. These units are linked by 3′ to 5′ phosphodiester bonds to form long polynucleotide chains The 3′-hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5′-hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group

questions.text: Several techniques such as PCR, in situ hybridization, RFLP, etc. require DNA strands to be separated for analysis. Heating is one of the most common methods to denature a dsDNA into single-stranded form. At a widely used temperature in molecular biology technique called Tm or melting temperature, what percentage of dsDNA is denatured?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50% Melting temperature or Tm The temperature when half (50%) of the helical structure is denatured. At lower temperature, the melted strands are re-associated; this is called annealing . When DNA is denatured, unstacking of bases occurs resulting in increased absorbance at 260 nm. This phenomenon is known as hyperchromicity.

questions.text: If one strand of DNA contains the sequence “ATCGCGTAACATGGATTCGG”, what will be the sequence of the complementary strand using the standard convention?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CCGAATCCATGTTACGCGAT DNA and RNA are directional molecules. They are always written in the sequence of 5’ to 3’. Phosphodiester bonds link the 3′- and 5′-carbons of adjacent monomers. Each end of a nucleotide polymer thus is distinct. We, therefore, refer to the “5′-end” or the “3′-end” of a polynucleotide, the 5′-end being that with a free or phosphorylated 5′-hydroxyl group. DNA sequences are complementary and antiparallel to each other. If one strand of DNA contains the sequence “ 5' ATCGCGTAACATGGATTCGG 3' ” the sequence of the complementary strand will be 5' CCGAATCCATGTTACGCGAT 3' Note: In the question or answer option if nothing is mentioned about the direction of the sequence, you have to automatically assume that they are asking in a 5'-3' direction as it is an internationally accepted convention.

questions.text: Restriction endonucleases also known as molecular scissors are enzymes widely used in molecular biology techniques such as gene cloning, recombinant DNA technology, RFLP, etc. These enzymes cleave:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Double-stranded DNA Restriction endonuclease Cleaves double-stranded DNA at palindromic sites/ restriction sites A palindromic sequence is a sequence in which both strands read the same when read in a 5’ to 3’ direction as shown below: 5' → AAGCTT - 3' 3' → TTCGAA - 5' RE are Found in bacteria They can create sticky ends or blunt ends

questions.text: All of the following statements are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Heterochromatin is the relatively uncondensed portion of DNA.

options.label: B
options.text: Euchromatin represents the transcriptionally active portions of the DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: Histones are positively charged because of the high content of basic amino acids in them.

options.label: D
options.text: Methylation of DNA will increase the condensed portions

questions.correct_answer: A. Heterochromatin is the relatively uncondensed portion of DNA.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heterochromatin is the relatively uncondensed portion of DNA. Heterochromatin Condensed DNA (not uncondensed) Tightly bound DNA which is transcriptionally inactive Euchromatin Uncondensed Loose DNA, which is transcriptionally active. Histones Rich in basic amino acids e. arginine and lysine (positive charge) . Highly conserved proteins across organisms. Methylation of DNA Leads to gene inactivation or heterochromatin formation. Mostly occurs at cytosine residue in DNA.

questions.text: Understanding the structure of DNA, and the process of replication, made us develop various drugs that interfere with DNA replication in pathogens. The type of bond seen between the phosphate group and 5’ carbon of ribose sugar within a nucleotide is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ester bond The question asks about the bond in a single nucleotide and not between two nucleotides. Hence the answer will be an ester bond and not a phosphodiester bond. Ester bond or Phosphoester bond >> Acid Anhydride Bond between 2 nucleotides Phosphodiester bond Bond between Phosphate & sugar with a nucleotide Ester or phosphoester bond The bond between 5’ or 3' carbon of sugar & Oxygen anion of phosphate is an ester bond (phosphoester or acid anhydride bond). Beta N-glycosidic bond is between N-base & sugar. Between two nucleotides, this phosphate group will form two C-O links (one with 5’ C of incoming sugar & other with 3’ carbon of the previous sugar), so it is known as a 3’5’ phosphodiester bond.

questions.text: All the human chromosomes are divided into four categories depending on the position of the centromere. Y chromosome falls into which of the following category?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acrocentric The Y chromosome is acrocentric

questions.text: The diseases occurring due to mutation in the mitochondrial genome are called mitochondrial disorders. These disorders mainly affect the brain and CNS due to defects in ETC and aerobic respiration. All of the following are mitochondrial disorders EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Incontinentia pigmenti Mitochondrial DNA disorders MELAS – Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes Leigh syndrome Leber hereditary optic neuropathy Kearns Sayre syndrome NARP syndrome – Neuropathy, Ataxia & Retinitis Pigmentosa MERRF - Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged-red fibers Incontinentia pigmenti (Bloch-Sulzberger syndrome) X-linked genetic disease Skin, hair, teeth & CNS manifestations

questions.text: Turner syndrome is a genetic disorder with a monosomy of the sex chromosome and genotype XO. In this disease, only females are affected. False about Turner’s syndrome are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal intelligence The question is asking about the true statement about Turner's syndrome out of all options . Only Normal intelligence is true and while all other options provide a false explanation of Turner's syndrome as explained below: Turner syndrome Genotype is XO Female is affected Only monosomy compatible with life Have zero Barr bodies (A normal female has one Barr body) Intelligence is normal

questions.text: X- linked recessive disease in males with clotting defects is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemophilia A X- linked recessive disease in males with the clotting defect is Hemophilia A. For other options refer to Mantra attached.

questions.text: True statement(s) among the following about inheritance of an X-linked recessive trait is/are: 50% of boys of carrier mothers are affected Transmitted through affected females Males are occasionally affected Most common sex-linked pattern 100% incidence of affected sons from an affected mother Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 4, and 5 are correct X-linked Recessive (XR) inheritance Most common sex-linked pattern Males are usually affected Transmitted through unaffected females In X- Linked inheritance , there is no male- to- male transmission . In the X-linked recessive trait, 50% of boys of carrier mothers are affected (Fig 1.) 100% incidence of affected sons from an affected mother suggests XR inheritance (Fig 2.) Fig 1- Inheritance from carrier mother Fig 2- Inheritance from affected mother

questions.text: The most lethal karyotype is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

45, YO The most lethal karyotype is 45, YO Monosomy is more dangerous than trisomy. Turner Syndrome(XO) is only monosomy compatible with life. 45, YO karyotype is fetal in utero and not compatible with life Monosomy In Autosomes In Sex Chromosome ● Not found ● Lethal ● Turner Syndrome (XO) ● Viable

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has short stature, coarse facies, stiffening of the joints, and mental retardation. His parents, a 7-year-old brother, and a 9-year-old sister, all are unaffected. Mother had a family history of a disease with similar progressive symptoms in one of her brothers who died at 16 years of age and in one of her nephews (her sister’s son). The patient’s mother is pregnant. The risk of the fetus having the same disease is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

25% The patient’s normal parents (unaffected father and carrier mother), one normal sister (normal daughter), and normal brother (normal son) again indicate an X-linked recessive inheritance according to the chart below. As the pedigree chart of the mother’s family shows no presence of disease in the mother (normal daughter .) but in one brother (affected son in fig.) and in the nephew from his sister (son of carrier daughter in fig.), it again confirms an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. Coarse facial features is a typical feature of Mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) and Hunter syndrome has an X-linked recessive pattern. Given X-linked recessive inheritance, the mother must have the abnormal allele on one of her X chromosomes (she is a carrier) in order for her son and brother to be affected. Her fetus has a 1/2 chance of being a boy and a 1/2 chance of being affected given male sex, resulting in a 1/4 (25%) overall risk of being affected.

questions.text: If both parents have sickle cell anemia, then the likelihood of children (offsprings) having the disease is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

100% Sickle cell anemia Inherited as AR . If both parents are affected, means both parents are homozygous for the trait as the recessive allele is expressed in only the homozygous state. Then 100 % offspring will inherit the disease. If Both parents are carriers then only 25% will be affected

questions.text: The mitochondrial genome is present only in Eukaryotes and constitutes about 1% of total cellular DNA. It is circular dsDNA like prokaryotic DNA and encodes for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

37 genes Mitochondrial DNA consists of 37 genes encoding for: 2 rRNA 22 tRNA 13 protein sub-units

questions.text: Double-stranded RNA is a useful tool for RNA interference and gene silencing technology. The structure of dsRNA resembles which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-DNA like conformation Double- stranded RNA exists in A- DNA - like conformation Usually, RNA is single stranded , and DNA is double- stranded . But in a few species, double- stranded RNA is found e.g. Rotavirus. For other options refer to mantra attached.

questions.text: Match the disorder with its trait of inheritance: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c, 2-f, 3-a, 4-e

Table:

#Mantra

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true/false about DNA? Two strands are held together by peptide bonds Non-covalent bonds in the sugar-phosphate backbone The most common DNA is Z- DNA The melting point of DNA is closely related to the Cytosine + Guanine content of DNA The distance spanned by one turn of B-DNA is 3.4nm Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-F, 2-F, 3-F, 4-T, 5-T DNA Structural features : 2 strands are held together by hydrogen bonds. There are covalent bonds (3’-5’ phosphodiester bonds) in the sugar-phosphate backbone. The most common DNA is B-DNA. The m elting point of DNA is closely related to the Cytosine Guanine content of DNA as C and G have three bonds, as compared to the two bonds present between A and T. A single turn of B-DNA about the long axis of the molecule contains 10 bp . The distance spanned by one turn of B-DNA is 3.4 nm (34 Aº). The width (helical diameter) of the double helix in B-DNA is 2 nm (20Aº).

questions.text: In a family, the mother is normal while the father has a genetic disease. All their daughters are carriers and sons are normal, what is the pattern of inheritance of disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

X-linked recessive (XR) In XR inheritance: The most common sex-linked pattern of inheritance (out of XD, XR & Y- linked inheritance) X- linked genes usually code for enzymes Males are usually affected Transmitted through unaffected females Here, there is no male-to-male transmission

Extraedge:

All Mucopolysaccharidosis are autosomal recessive, except Hunter’s disease – X-linked recessive All Sphingolipidosis are autosomal recessive Fabry’s disease – X-linked recessive.

questions.text: One gene one protein theory states that one gene can give rise to one protein. Following is/are exceptions to one gene one protein theory:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both a & b 20,000 genes in humans give rise to a total of 2.5 lakh proteins . Which cannot be explained by this theory. This can be explained because there are processes such as RNA editing: Apo B48 & Apo B100 are synthesized from the same mRNA due to differences in RNA Editing/Chemical modification of RNA/ Differential RNA Processing In the liver , apo B mRNA is 100% translated to produce apoB100 In the intestine, the same apo B mRNA is acted upon by the cytosine deaminase enzyme which converts one of the cytosine bases (in the mRNA) to uracil converting the codon CAA to UAA (stop codon). Later during translation of this mRNA protein synthesis gets prematurely terminated with the final protein missing some of the amino acids of apo B100 protein. This short version of the protein is apoB48. Which lacks the hepatic receptor-binding domain (missing amino acids). It has different properties than apoB100. Alternate splicing: Multiple RNA forms can be generated from the same gene transcript by alternate splicing which gives rise to different proteins.

questions.text: In which of the inheritance, if the father is affected no offspring is affected, but if the mother is affected, all offspring are affected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitochondrial Mitochondrial Inheritance Mitochondria is derived only from the mother Mitochondrial disease has a high incidence as: Mitochondrial DNA repair cannot occur Introns are not present Continuous exposure to the oxygen free radicals Therefore, have more chances of mutations in mitochondrial DNA Mitochondrial Inheritance Affected mother will transmit the disease to all offspring X linked disease No male-to-male transmission Y linked disease Affected father will transmit the disease to all son Autosomal disease Equal frequency of these disease in male and female

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient visited a physician with complaints of increasing fatigue and muscle aches during exercise. He recalls avoiding sports activities in his younger years because he was not able to keep up. Stress testing reveals normal cardiac function, but blood tests show gradually increasing levels of serum lactic acid and ammonia under resting conditions. His physician suspects a mitochondrial DNA disorder that affects mitochondrial function due to mutation in mitochondrial genes. Which of the following options gives the names of mitochondrial pathways affected in this patient and also lists the compound linking these pathways? Glycogenolysis, glycolysis, and glucose 6-P Citric acid cycle, electron transport chain, and α-ketoglutarate Citric acid cycle and urea cycle, and fumarate Glycogen synthesis, gluconeogenesis, and malate Citric acid and urea cycle, and arginine Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 5 are correct Mutation in the mitochondrial genome mainly affects oxidative phosphorylation leading to low ATP and anaerobic glycolysis with lactic acid accumulation, especially under stressful conditions such as exercise due to depletion of blood oxygen saturation. A vicious cycle of exercise intolerance leading to muscle inactivity with fewer mitochondria exacerbates myopathy (muscle weakness and incoordination) in mitochondrial disorders. All the reactions of the citric acid cycle and some of the initial reactions of the urea cycle are located primarily in the mitochondria, whereas glycogen and glucose metabolism pathways primarily occur in the cytosol (Options A and D are excluded). α-keto glutarate and fumarate are intermediates of the citric acid cycle, but only fumarate is an intermediate of both the citric acid and urea cycles (Option B is excluded). Fumarate and arginine are produced from argininosuccinate in the urea cycle, after which arginine is converted to ornithine to yield urea (option E is excluded) and fumarate is converted to malate and then oxaloacetate in the citric acid cycle.
